it would be a big channel, so hot-wallet risk. for lightning user withdraw/deposit it's harder as you have to balance liquidity and you never know who will withdraw. also lightning is bitcoin only, liquid is multi-asset like L-USDt etc. also c-lightning can work on top of liquid.

software changes require physical intervention by 2/3rds of the HSM operators. relying parties, users, etc also can run full-nodes so the model is similar to bitcoin. a UASF could be done to replace the block-signers or a subset of them if there was a disagreement.

is the part-constellation equally spaced? can #bitcoin have them?

different layers are optimized for different use cases: bitcoin mainchain: censor resistant payments & cold storage lightning: instant retail and micropayments liquid: fast confidential multi-asset exchange traders

liquid is a bitcoin layer2/sidechain: a fast, reliable way to move Bitcoin & Tether between exchanges. during this lull in the trading storm, practice Liquid exchange transfer, so you're prepared for the storm & 100x fees to avoid liquidation or losing trades due to network load.

Which use case? More scalable Bitcoin or scalable fiatcoin? Have ideas actually, but have limits to resources sadly. If there's a way to fund things we always have more ideas than time and more than protocol/applied crypto/system programmers can keep up with..

c-lightning has support for liquid and bitcoin, so lightning can work on top of both. (L-BTC and non-confidential so far, but general liquid assets and CT to follow). if lightning is layer2, then maybe liquid is layer1.5

as range proofs are big the in-practice bytes/block maybe bigger, bitcoin transaction vs signature will be smaller than liquid transaction vs signatore+rangeproof. but new liquid min fee rate is smaller at 0.1sat/vbyte so it all balances out approximately.

same as bitcoin 4MW (liquid has segwit also and the confidential transaction range proofs are same discounted weight as signatures). but the blocks are every minute so 10x. but then liquid transactions are probably about 10x bigger due to confidential transactions. so about same

now now. lets start with a clear cut case: bitcoin. wiki policy is not pernicious, it's pragmatic and reactive to observed problems - spam and edit wars by paid marketers of premined alt-coins.

Fair enough, thanks. But not all. Anyway point stands: high tier Bitcoin magazines are better sources than main stream media. Would you be willing to support that policy change for Bitcoin (as distinct from organized self promoted alt coins, general pyramid scams, Ponzi's etc)

yes, skimmed it. he hates crypto, even Bitcoin, i know. as said I sympathize with the torrent of paid promotion attempts, the spam. but that is not bitcoin. however MSM quality bar being objectively worse accuracy than higher tier bitcoin magazines is a robust point and stands.

reducing the accuracy of content and quality of citations of Bitcoin related content serves no-one. I imagine the determined paid "spam" / spin is unlikely to be as extant with bitcoin as no one owns a premine, everyone who has bitcoin either mined it or bought it, like gold etc.

my suggestion would be to move to the middle-ground. a quality bar of 2-3 publications like @BitcoinMagazine and @coindesk. they do not do paid placements, and maintain independent and technically accurate reporting standards, far in excess of most MSM bitcoin coverage.

well sympathy on the spam, i don't much care about alts, where I agree they're often aggressively incentivized as they own large premines. but using inaccurate MSM effectively has been used (whether intentional or not) to degrade the accuracy of wiki articles relating to bitcoin.

well IMO the "must use MSM source" rule should be dropped for Bitcoin because the MSM articles are inferior in quality and accuracy to the middle ground, the better crypto publications like bitcoin magazine & coindesk. I think wikipedians said this rule doesn't apply generally?

It's a way of storing value that is resistant to confiscation and censorship. For example, Hong Kong protestors recently had $10m+ seized from their Citibank account on order of China. Bitcoin protects savings from that.
